comments.commentBody: That scenario has played out in my mind, and it doesn't end well.  Cruz was too extreme to make it through the primaries, but I can envision how christians and conservatives could twist their beliefs enough to support Pence.

EinT: The federal and state governments will return excess income tax payments. I have experienced this. If they correct an error in your income tax return and find an overpayment, they return it with interest.

(Note that I referred to "income tax". So many people forget all about sales tax and other taxes. That distorts their perception of the tax burden.)

It says the Hutterites live in areas with similar levels of pollutants, so it's unlikely that fresh air is the causal factor. Most telling, though, is the data indicating that the bacteria-containing dust is sufficient to induce the same protective effects in mice. It's pretty convincing.

If I understood this article (not the original study) it claims that the living environments are quite similar between the Amish (Indiana) and Hutterite (North Dakota) other than the barns. The fact that the dust impacts mice so distinctly (not proof as mice are not people) and consistent with the asthma rates is also striking.

Well, 35C would be 95F or thereabouts, which does seem unlikely, but there was a heatwave, and I know temps have been up in the 80s up there. Quibbling about the exact temperature at a particular time is not a good argument, petty and beside the point. Daily spot temp is unhelpful at best, we're talking weeks. But there is that silly Arthopolis site that has had the same temperature for several years now; apparently Russian temps require a careful looksee.

"Temperatures have soared in western Russia’s Yamal tundra this summer. Across Siberia, some provinces warmed an additional 10 degrees Fahrenheit beyond normal. In the fields, large bubbles of vegetation appeared above the melting permafrost — strange pockets of methane or, more likely, water. Record fires blazed through dry Russian grassland.

"In one of the more unusual symptoms of unseasonable warmth, long-dormant bacteria appear to be active. For the first time since 1941, anthrax struck western Siberia. Thirteen Yamal nomads were hospitalized, including four children, the Siberian Times reported. The bacteria took an even worse toll on wildlife, claiming some 1,500 reindeer since Sunday."
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/07/28/anthrax-si...

Anyways, people sickened from exposure to anthrax from a thawing reindeer, and arguing *exactly* how hot it was is mildly irrelevant.
Here, the source is not a significant factor.

LVF, I think you are looking too hard at superficialities. Also, missing the words "I'm reminded of" which, to me, don't suggest a detailed analogy. Your comment reminds me of something about the forest and the trees. You know.

Dan, thanks for the support and the documentation. I could add things like the salt tax, which was a burden to poor people for the obvious reason and possibly also because nobility were often exempted from taxes ("if I remember correctly"). Worse, the salt tax varied dramatically from one region to another for no reason except random variation in historical development of taxation. In sum, as far as my lack of expertise can say, it seems to have been an irrational system.

You're very welcome Thomas, and the historical comparison brings to mind another historical comparison. The internal tariffs in France were one factor in the French Revolution. Religious strife was not too much of an issue, but societal class was a big one, as with India. Unfair taxes were the source of a few successful revolutions really.

I think India had better straighten out its class and tax disparities, because with the constant religious strife and other problems on every border, a revolution is maybe more likely than they think.

I'm reminded of France under the Ancien Regime: every region had an entirely different tax structure, there were (if I remember correctly) internal tariffs, and it was an internal mess.  The Revolution got rid of that.  Nothing less was able to succeed.  Fortunate for India that a revolution wasn't required.

Fascinating article that tells us much about human nature! Do we fully understand the placebo effect? Should we consider it like a drug, a procedure, a surgery, and so on? Should we have a trial comparing excercise, placebo effect, and a procedure? Our brain is a mysterious thing.

This is all nonsense. Patients with disabling severe pain will not volunteer for randomized studies. All these studies have selection bias and many include patients that have never tried physical therapy before.
Unfortunately, the misinformation confuses patients just like the antvaccers have

re "consensus": it's a word, in English (or American if you prefer).

Words are ways to represent things, they are never precise.

You could say there's a consensus that gravity works, it keeps us on the ground. But the fact that gravity exists is a consensus that is only slightly higher than agreement amongst expert climate scientists. Whether it's 90% of 97%, there are very few things on earth that experts agree about that much.

This is not a political reality. It's a real reality. If you live long enough (I'd say no more than 20 years) the time denial will be possible to support will run out.

Insults are not arguments.

I'm a physician and an epidemiologist. On August 16, 2015 I herniated my C7 spinal disc. I have read the literature on spinal fusion and agree that there is no statistical proof of spinal fusion's benefit.

The clinical studies are extremely limited. The largest I found randomized two arms each of 38 patients. As my symptoms worsened, I began to lose the reflexes in my left arm. In order to avoid pain, I had to stop physical therapy and become basically debilitated. (I had been diligent in physical therapy for 2 1/2 months prior to this.) I had surgery on Jan 4th. Immediately post surgery, I lost the persistent numbness and tingling. my reflexes improved. Pain dramatically decreased. I got a lot better.

I don't think that the patients who have the worst symptoms are willing to be randomized. I was willing to undergo surgery even with a limited expectation of benefit. It concerns me greatly that anyone - clinician, insurance exec or public health official - would consider the available evidence as proof that cervical spinal fusion surgery is not effective. Sometimes the researchers' reach exceeds their grasp.

Anyone who doubts that Clinton is the better candidate should read this documented list of reasons to support her (read by 7400, so please continue to share): https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/open-letter-sanders-supporters-scott-s-sm...
I'd feel safer with Ivanka over Pence.

Two months ago, I was unable to walk.  After a skiing accident three and a half years ago, my left knee became increasingly troublesome.  Eventually the knee became unstable, hugely swollen, and exquisitely painful.  An MRI showed two tears in the medial meniscus.  Two months after surgery, my knee is not swollen, and I feel only minor pain after miles of walking.  This is an excellent result.  This is not a placebo effect.

Years ago I was fresh out of college as an aeronautical engineer in the post-Viet-Nam aerospace bust. This was 2 years after the bill board outside Seattle that said "will the last person leaving Seattle turn out the lights?"

http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&File_Id=...

I was working for a dinky outfit headed by a psycho ... and I'll omit the ugliest of the details that went from there ... but there comes a time when anyone with a brain says "BASTA!" and you leave -- decide to do something else.

There's always a big price for this -- I paid it. My marriage evaporated, I went back to graduate school to change careers, that was pretty awful frankly. But I got out of the insanity.

To all the Republicans out there -- you need to get out of the insanity. But I understand about prices to be paid. I was still young, didn't have kids.

If you feel really trapped, I'm sorry for you. But the New York Times doesn't permit me to use the right metaphors for how abused you are ... they are too crude.
And all Europe laughs, and cries.
EGO!

Sadly, that is my thinking as well. I felt that during President Obama's time in the White House, I read and heard a lot of racist remarks concerning the first family. I think that when Ms. Clinton wins the presidency, we will see, hear, and read more sexist and misogynistic views.

That's why I think it's good that Ms. Clinton is tough, aggressive, controlled and has a thick skin (everything thatDonald Trump is not) -- she's been through 11 hours of Benghazi testifying and came out of it unscathed. I hope she can handle 4 years of worse than that.

As usual, I have a "whaaa?" response, BA. What does "result of a parking violation ---> boot" mean? It seems to mean that a parking violation results in the boot on one's car. Are you saying that this is a normal thing? Perhaps in The City? Another reason not to spend time there, perchance? Broken Windows and What Not?

Trump is a rich man's son, and would never have survived the business world without his Daddy's repeated financial bailouts. Trump might enjoy ripping a critic/competitor's "throat out," as Michael says here. But it's only because of who he has been allowed to become -- a vessel for a scary bunch of resentful people who were left behind in the economic recovery.

Oh, also the ultra-rich 1 percent. Those guys will never get rich enough.
But the shrewd maker of big deals that Trump has tried to brand himself as -- no way. How many bankruptcies has he filed? How many employees and contractors has he stiffed? And -- big surprise -- he won't release his tax returns.

All that, plus he's so thin-skinned he publically got mad a mother and her crying baby at a rally. I mean, really.
And they have Ichiro, who not only fills the same role without the baggage, but is still hitting.
correlation is not causation, but hey, why not blame the failure of 25 guys on just one of them?
Hear, hear!

There's no way to know what's in someone's heart, but I'm leaning towards the things that ARod says being more than damage control or PR. Look at Barry Bonds: he's Miami's hitting coach, and he's never really admitted anything about juicing. ARod doesn't shy away from it anymore, and you don't even have to wait for an interviewer to bring it up. Somebody suggested asking his teammates what they think of him. It's been done, often, and the vast majority of them feel lucky to be on the same team as he is. I think even Jeter has made up with him. He's got one of the greatest baseball IQ's in history, and he seems to have learned what Bonds, Pete Rose and a lot of others never did about taking responsibility. Sometimes you can learn more about what not to do from someone who did it than from someone who never did. Now, if he's still a slumlord, that's another story, but in baseball, if the new ARod is for real, the game, and the team, should take advantage of what he has to give.
Which peers did you talk to who detest him?
Amongst his range of juvenile unsavority uglinesses, Trump is a sadist. Lowering the bar every day, in every way, that's our GOPosaurus.
